p:
After fermentation, an obvious decline of 60% in glucose was observed as compared with the control. This is probably due to the utilization of glucose to produce compounds such as organic acids, lipids, pyruvate, and enzymes, among others, by Y. lipolytica
23, 24 . In comparison, fructose was not used by Y. lipolytica as no significant change was observed. This observation was in accordance with a previous finding which showed that fructose is only used after any available glucose has been completely consumed due to the fact that the Y. lipolytica hexokinase has a low affinity for fructose
25, 26 . Similarly, sucrose, which remained unchanged after fermentation, also cannot be utilized by Y. lipolytica because of the lack of the sucrose-cleaving enzyme invertase
27 . Meanwhile, mannose, which was absent in the control and blank PK, was released after fermentation. The ability to release mannose by Y. lipolytica was probably due to the secreted mannosidases. An exo-Î±-mannosidase was characterized in Y. lipolytica
28 .
